Article Mechanistic insights into sulfation-induced deactivation of CoMn2O4/CeTiO x catalyst under low-temperature SCR conditions Ning Luo a Fengyu Gao a * Chengzhi Wang b Honghong Yi a Shunzheng Zhao a Yuansong Zhou a Shangfeng Du c Xiaolong Tang a * a Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants School of Energy and Environmental Engineering University of Science and Technology Beijing Beijing 100083 China Beijing Key Laboratory of Resource-oriented Treatment of Industrial Pollutants, School of Energy and Environmental Engineering, University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing 100083, China b Henan Academy of Sciences, Institute of Chemistry, Zhengzhou 450046, Henan, China Henan Academy of Sciences Institute of Chemistry Zhengzhou Henan 450046 China Henan Academy of Sciences, Institute of Chemistry, Zhengzhou 450046, Henan, China c School of Chemical Engineering, University of Birmingham, Edgbaston, Birmingham B15 2TT, UK School of Chemical Engineering University of Birmingham Edgbaston Birmingham B15 2TT UK School of Chemical Engineering, University of Birmingham, Edgbaston, Birmingham B15 2TT, UK * Corresponding author. The problem of water and sulfur poisoning in flue gas atmosphere remains a significant obstacle for low-temperature deNO x catalysts. This study investigated the sulfation mechanism of the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) catalyst during the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 under conditions containing H2O and SO2 at 150 °C. Employing a comprehensive suite of time-resolved analysis and characterization techniques, the evolution of sulfate species was systematically categorized into three stages: initial rapid surface sulfate accumulation, the transformation of surface sulfates to bulk metal sulfates, and partial sulfates decomposition after the removal of H2O and SO2. These findings indicate that bulk metal sulfates irreversibly deactivate the catalyst by distorting active component lattices and consuming oxygen vacancies, whereas surface sulfates (including ammonium sulfates and surface-coordinated metal sulfates) cause reversible performance loss through decomposition. Furthermore, the competitive adsorption of H2O and SO2 significantly influences the catalytic efficiency, with H2O suppressing SO2 adsorption while simultaneously enhancing the formation of Brönsted acid sites. This research underscores the critical role of sulfate dynamics on catalyst performance, revealing the enhanced SO2 resistance of the Eley-Rideal mechanism facilitated by the Ce-Ti support relative to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood pathway. Collectively, the study unravels the complex interplay of sulfate dynamics influencing catalyst performance and provides potential approaches to mitigate deactivation in demanding atmospheric conditions. Graphical Abstract Time-resolved analysis reveals that low-temperature NH3-SCR on CoMn2O4/CeTiOₓ proceeds through rapid surface sulfation, bulk sulfate-driven irreversible deactivation, and partial sulfate decomposition with activity recovery, clarifying key deactivation and regeneration mechanisms. Keywords Selective catalytic reduction with NH3 CoMn2O4/CeTiO x H2O and SO2 resistance Surface sulfate Bulk sulfate 1 Introduction Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) with NH3 is widely employed to remove NO x from stationary sources [1]. Traditional SCR systems operate at 300–400  °C upstream of desulfurization and dust removal units, where high concentrations of SO2 and particulates significantly accelerate catalyst deactivation. In contrast, low-temperature SCR (LT-SCR, 120–250  °C) systems placed downstream of these units experience cleaner flue gas conditions, significantly reducing poisoning risks and enabling more stable and energy-efficient NO x removal [2–4]. Extensively researched de-NO x catalysts for low-temperature SCR include traditional metal oxides, such as V-based, Ce-based, Cu-based, Fe-based, and Mn-based catalysts, zeolites, as well as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) and their derivatives [5]. Among these, transition metal oxide catalysts, particularly manganese-based systems, are promising LT-SCR catalysts due to their versatile valence states and excellent redox properties, achieving high NO x conversion at temperatures below 200  °C [6–9]. Nevertheless, even trace levels of residual SO2 from flue gas desulfurization processes remain problematic, rapidly causing catalyst deactivation [10,11]. Various strategies, including surface acidity modulation, redox property tuning, and introduction of sulfur-trapping additives, have been explored to mitigate SO2 poisoning [10,12–15]. Recent advances, such as hydrophobic surface functionalization, have further enhanced the H2O and SO2 tolerance of manganese-based catalysts, maintaining high catalytic stability even in harsh reaction environments [16]. Meanwhile, current research also highlights spinel-type (Mn-Co, Mn-Ni, Mn-Cu) and Ce-modified manganese oxides as effective solutions due to controlled sulfate deposition or preferential SO2 adsorption on sacrifice sites (such as ceria) [14,15,17–21]. Specifically, Feng et al. [22,23] have reported that strong Mn-Co interactions can promote redox cycling, enhance surface acidity, and improve SO2 tolerance in SCR catalysts. Moreover, Gd-modified Mn-Co layered double hydroxide (LDH)-derived oxides demonstrate significantly improved catalytic activity and enhanced resistance to H2O/SO2 poisoning [24]. Wang et al. [2] discovered that a dynamic balance of sulfate formation and decomposition on CeO2 surfaces, observed via in-situ TEM and theoretical analysis, effectively minimizes SO2-induced deactivation of MnO x /CeO2 catalysts, maintaining high catalytic activity in the presence of 200 × 10–6 SO2 for 1000 h at 250 °C. However, the catalytic activity decreases somewhat when the temperature is 200 °C. In the study by Zhang et al. [1], the impact of temperature on Ce-TiO2 catalysts in the presence of SO2 was observed as follows: At 180 °C, the formation of sulfate/sulfite significantly inhibited SCR activity by limiting NH4 + adsorption. At 240 °C, the ongoing accumulation of sulfate/sulfite began to impact SCR transformation. By 300 °C, the detrimental effects of sulfate were mitigated, leading to a partial restoration of catalyst performance, illustrating that higher temperatures help alleviate the negative impacts of sulfate accumulation. Importantly, significant deactivation persists at temperatures below 200  °C, particularly in realistic conditions where both H2O and SO2 coexist underscoring major gaps in understanding low-temperature poisoning mechanism [21,25,26]. Recent studies have also indicated that Mn-Ce co-modified TiO2 catalysts and MoO3-modified Ce-Ti catalysts enhance SCR performance and tolerance of SO2 and H2O under low temperatures [27,28]. However, the effectiveness tends to decline below 180  °C, and the underlying mechanism of sulfate-induced deactivation remains insufficiently understood during long-term exposure. Current literature illustrates varying catalyst responses to SO2 and H2O exposure at low temperatures (< 180  °C). Our research team conducted a wide exploration of the resistance to water and sulfur at low temperatures in transition metal catalysts. Most studies report an initial decline to a stable activity plateau, followed by nearly complete recovery upon removal of poisoning gases [3,7,15,18,29–32]; however, some catalysts exhibit a plateau but limited recovery after the removal of poisoning gases [33–35]. Additionally, a few studies indicated a continuous decline in activity upon exposure to water and sulfur, with nearly no recovery upon removal of poisoning gases [36]. Accordingly, differences in catalyst performance under poisoning conditions have been linked to the distinct roles of Brönsted and Lewis acid sites in SCR reaction pathways and NO x conversion [37]. Complex interactions involving metal sulfates and ammonium sulfates have also been proposed as contributing factors [38,39]. However, such explanations do not fully account for the significant variability observed in water and sulfur resistance among different catalysts. The diverse responses suggest that the type, morphology, and distribution of sulfate species, as well as their dynamic transformations on the catalyst surface, play a critical role in determining catalyst stability and the extent of activity recovery. These factors remain poorly understood. In this context, we selected the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) catalyst for its notable long-term stability under H2O and SO2 exposure and distinctive two-phase catalytic behavior, displaying both stable activity plateaus and rapid activity decline. This dual-phase behavior offers an ideal platform for investigating sulfate species dynamics and clarifying their roles in catalyst poisoning. By applying a systematic, time-resolved analysis, we segmented the poisoning process into distinct phases: initial, fluctuation, deactivation, and recovery. Characterization using comprehensive analytical methods, including thermogravimetric-differential thermal gravimetry (TG-DTA), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman, Fourtier transformed infrared (FT-IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and in-situ diffused reflectance Fourtier transformed infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS). This detailed mechanistic approach aims to unravel the dynamic interplay between sulfate species and catalyst performance, providing critical insights to guide the development of more durable transition metal-based low-temperature SCR catalysts under realistic environmental conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The fresh catalyst CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) used in this study is identical to that reported in our previous work [40]. Then the CMCT was subjected to a standard NH3-SCR with H2O + SO2 co-feeding treatments to obtain sulfated samples at different exposure stages. Detailed synthesis procedures and sample information are provided in the Supporting Information. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized by techniques including SEM, XPS, XRD, TG-DTA, FT-IR, Raman, and in-situ DRIFTS. Detailed experimental conditions and procedures are provided in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Activity measurement The NH3-SCR reaction and the poisoning effect of SO2 and H2O on the SCR reaction were carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor. Approximately 0.10 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was used in each experiment. The reaction conditions were controlled as follows: 0.10 g of catalyst, 500 × 10–6 NO, 500 × 10–6 NH3, 8 vol% O2, N2 balanced, 100 × 10–6 SO2 and 10 vol% H2O (when used), and a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 32000 h–1. After the blended gas was fed into the reactor, the outlet concentrations of SO2, NO x , NO2, and NH3 were continuously detected by an FT-IR spectrometer (Nicolet IS 50). The NO x conversion was calculated as follows: (1) NO x conversion ( % ) = [ NO x ] in - [ NO x ] out [ NO x ] in × 100 (2) N 2 selectivity ( % ) = ( 1 - 2 × [ N 2 O ] out [ NO x ] in + [ NH 3 ] in - [ NO x ] out - [ NH 3 ] out ) × 100 (3) Changes of NO x conversion ( % ) = ( NO x conversion with NO x conversion without - 1 ) × 100 where [NO x ] = [NO] + [NO2], the subscripts of (in) and (out) refer to the concentration of the corresponding gases before (inlet) and after (outlet) the catalytic reactor, respectively. The subscripts (with) and (without) refer to the NO x conversion of the reaction system with and without H2O and SO2, respectively. The outlet concentration of SO3 was measured using an isopropanol absorption method followed by titration with sodium hydroxide. In this method, gaseous SO3 is absorbed and converted into acid (H2SO4) in solution, and its concentration is calculated based on the volume of NaOH consumed. Detailed procedures and calculation formulas are provided in the Supporting Information. To investigate the changes in gas-induced uptake of the catalyst at different reaction stages, TG analysis was employed to monitor the mass changes of the catalyst under gas atmospheres [41,42]. TG was employed to assess the relative uptake behavior of NO, NH3, and SO2 on the catalyst surface at different reaction stages. The catalyst was pretreated in N2 at 150  °C for 1  h with a gas flow of 100 mL min–1, then exposed to mixed gas atmospheres (NO/NH3/SO2, or combinations thereof, N2 balanced) for 1  h, followed by inert gas purging. To accommodate the variable equilibrium times and ongoing reactions under multi-component conditions, a normalized response integral was calculated over a fixed time window (30  min), representing the cumulative adsorption-reaction response strength for each gas component. Based on this, a relative selectivity index S A/B was introduced to semi-quantitatively compare the competitive contribution of gases A and B, defined as: (4) A A / B = I A / I B C A / C B where I A and I B are the integrated normalized TG responses attributed to components A and B within the 30 min interval, and C A, C B are their inlet concentrations. Since the direct separation of mass uptake in multi-gas systems is not feasible, I A was estimated based on the contribution ratio of single-gas response areas: (5) I A = I total × I A single I A single + I B single In which, I total is the total integrated response under the mixed-gas condition, and I A single and I B single are the single-gas response integrals for components A and B. This index reflects the relative preference of the catalyst for different gases under competitive conditions. Detailed calculation steps are provided in the Supporting Information. The relative turnover frequency (TOF) was conducted to compare the activities of the different catalysts. The relative TOF of NO was calculated on a per-Mn basis. Although both Mn and Co may participate in the SCR process, Mn was chosen for normalization due to its dominant redox contribution for NH3-SCR in the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x system, as suggested by our previous reports [40]. For systems where both metals contribute significantly, TOF per total metal site may be more appropriate. The relative TOF (s–1) of NO over each Mn atom at different temperatures was calculated by the following equation: (6) TOF ( S - 1 ) = ( P ν / RT ) X NO m cat β Mn M Mn Here P is the standard atmospheric pressure (1.01 × 10–5 Pa); ν is the flow rate of NO (0.10 mL min–1); R is the proportional constant (8.314 J mol–1 K–1); T is the temperature (K); X NO is the NO conversion of the catalysts (%); m cat is the mass of the catalysts (0.02 g); β Mn is the Mn loading (%) and M Mn is the molar mass of Mn (54.94 g mol–1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Performance of NH3-SCR activity As shown in Fig. 1(a) , the long-term NH3-SCR stability of the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) at 150 °C in the presence of H2O and SO2 was proceeded through four distinct phases: The initial stable SCR reaction phase (CMCT-I), where NO x conversion remained consistently at nearly 100% for the first 8 h; the fluctuating activity phase under exposure to H2O and SO2 (CMCT-F), with NO x conversion rate decreasing and fluctuating between 84%–87% from 15 to 42 h, with 15 h as a characteristic point; the activity decline phase under prolonged exposure to H2O and SO2 (CMCT-D), during which the NO x conversion continuously decreased to 67% by 65  h, with 45  h identified as the onset of accelerated deactivation; and the recovery phase (CMCT-T), during which the NO x conversion gradually rebounded to above 90% after the removal of H2O and SO2, followed by an additional 8 h of SCR reaction. Comparative data between CMCT-I and CMCT-T showed a decrease in deNO x activity by 5%–10% and N2 selectivity by 1%–3%. Throughout the experiment, SO2 concentration at the inlet and outlet initially increased and then decreased, with none detected after 42 h, and no SO3 was detected during the reaction (Fig. S1 and Table S1). 3.2 Characterization of sulfate species on crystal and surface structure To investigate the effects of sulfation time on the surface morphology and sulfur distribution of CMCT at different sulfation stages, SEM-EDS analyses were conducted on CMCT-F, CMCT-D, and CMCT-T samples, focusing on changes in particle morphology and elemental mapping, particularly for sulfur (Fig. S2). The fresh CMCT catalyst exhibited uniform and smooth surface features, confirming a homogeneous distribution of Mn, Co, Ce, and Ti and an absence of sulfur. After 15 h of sulfation (CMCT-F), the catalyst surface developed slight roughness in certain areas, with faint sulfur signals detected in specific regions. Following 45 h of sulfation (CMCT-D), there was a significant increase in surface deposits and further roughening, accompanied by a notable enhancement in sulfur signals. After 65 h of sulfation and an additional 8 h of SCR reaction (CMCT-T), the surface deposits and sulfur signals were somewhat reduced. However, EDS still revealed residual sulfur on the catalyst, supporting that a significant fraction of sulfur species remains on or near the catalyst surface. The crystal phase structure changes of the CMCT catalyst at different reaction stages were analyzed by XRD, as shown in Fig. S3(a). The diffraction peaks of the initial sample (CMCT) in the range of 10°–90° 2θ correspond to the cubic fluorite structure of the CeO2 phase (JCPDF#34-0394), while the spinel-type structure of CoMn2O4 (JCPDF#18-0408) and the Ce2Ti2O7 phase (JCPDF#47-0667) were also detected, indicating the presence of Ce, Ti, and CoMn composite oxide structures in the initial sample. At different reaction stages, slight lattice changes were observed in the XRD patterns. As shown in Fig. S3(b), a subtle shift in the peak around 26°–35° suggests local lattice distortion. In Fig. S3(c), variations in both intensity and position of peaks within the 44°–60° range further reflect structural adjustments on the catalyst surface. Notably, the peak shifts and broadening near 29° and 48° were more pronounced during the sulfation process, indicating the dynamic evolution of the crystalline structure. Using TG-DTG, the thermal stability of CMCT catalyst at different sulfated phases was investigated. As shown in Fig. 1(b), all samples exhibited minimal mass loss within the 200–500 °C range, which is consistent with the thermal decomposition of (NH4)2SO4 (200–350 °C) and NH4HSO4 (350–500 °C) [43], suggesting the formation of ammonium bisulfate during sulfation. Between 500–800 °C, significant mass losses were observed, specifically at 641 and 726 °C for CMCT-F, 726 and 735 °C for CMCT-D, and at 758 °C for CMCT-T. These peaks are attributed to the decomposition of metal oxides and metal sulfates formed at different sulfation stages [44,45]. Given the complexity of sulfate species in the catalyst system, water washing was employed to eliminate soluble species and facilitate the identification of residual, less soluble sulfates via thermal analysis. After water washing (Fig. 1(c)), the residual mass loss of these samples in the 600–800 °C range was maintained between 4.36% and 4.69%, which is higher than that of the original CMCT (4.28%), indicating the presence of insoluble sulfate. Comparative TG analysis was performed to investigate the evolution and distribution of sulfate species during catalyst sulfation and deactivation (Fig. 1(d)). The yellow and light blue areas represent the total weight loss of sulfated catalysts at different reaction stages, while the dark blue corresponds to the weight loss of water-washed samples at the same stages. Compared with the fresh CMCT, the low-temperature weight loss (< 500  °C) is attributed to the decomposition of ammonium sulfates (AS/ABS), which are fully water-soluble and thus not observed after water washing. The content of these sulfates showed a rise-fall-rise trend: initially increasing, then decreasing and rising again after the removal of H2O and SO2. The high-temperature region (> 500  °C) reflects metal oxides and metal sulfates, whose content increased sharply and then gradually declined. Water washing enables the distinction between water-soluble and water-insoluble metal sulfates: the decrease in high-temperature weight loss after washing (the difference between the light blue and dark blue areas) is attributed to metal/metal sulfates, while the remaining high-temperature weight loss (dark blue area with slashes) corresponds to water-insoluble metal sulfates. The content of water-soluble metal sulfates (light blue area with slashes) can be determined by subtracting the amount of water-insoluble metal sulfates from the total content. Notably, at the deactivation stage (CMCT-D), this residual reached 0.41%, suggesting that insoluble sulfates are a major contributor to catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, after prolonged sulfation (> 30 h), white solids were observed on the inner wall of the reaction tube (Fig. S4(a)). FT-IR analysis (Fig. S4(b)) revealed characteristic peaks at 615, 1111, 1402, and 3135 cm–1, which are attributed to ammonium sulfate species, most likely (NH4)2SO4 and/or NH4HSO4, formed by the reaction of NH3 with SO2/SO3 under humid conditions [46–48]. The evolution of surface species during sulfation was examined by FT-IR spectroscopy (Fig. S5). As the reaction progressed, the FT-IR peaks at 3422 and 1620 cm–1 observed in the CMCT-I are attributed to physiosorbed water on the surface of metal oxides, gradually weakened and nearly disappeared in CMCT-F [49,50]. Meanwhile, new peaks appeared at 1070, 1115, and 1383 cm–1 in CMCT-D and CMCT-T, corresponding to surface sulfate species with different coordination modes [51,52]. Raman spectroscopy further revealed the structural evolution of the metal oxides. The CeO2-related peak at 461 cm–1 decreased and shifted, suggesting lattice distortion or interaction with SO4 2–, while peaks at 194 and 630 cm–1, assigned to Co3O4 and Mn2O3 also weakened, indicating partial reduction or surface reconstruction [40]. Water-washed samples were analyzed to assess sulfate solubility. Most sulfate-related FT-IR peaks disappeared after washing, while the band at 1115 cm–1 remained. In the Raman spectra, the CeO2 peak at 461 cm–1 partially recovered after washing, whereas the low-frequency peaks remained shifted. These results indicate that strongly bound metal sulfates and irreversible changes in the metal oxide lattice contribute to the structural evolution. Fig. 2 presents a comprehensive Raman mapping analysis of the catalysts at different reaction stages, including the fresh catalyst (CMCT), sulfated catalysts (CMCT-F and CMCT-D), and the recovered catalyst (CMCT-T). For each sample, average Raman spectra, 2D spectral mappings, and spatial distribution maps of characteristic metal-oxygen vibrations (Ce–O, Ti–O, Co–O, Mn–O) are shown. The average spectra reflect the overall structural evolution, while the 2D mapping plots illustrate the spatial distribution and intensity variation across the catalyst surface. To ensure a reliable comparison of compositional changes, all spectra were normalized to the 350 cm–1 band, which corresponds to Ti–O vibrations in CeTiO x support, and selected for its high intensity and inertness, in contrast to the redox-sensitive CeO2 and Mn–O, Co–O bands. In the fresh catalyst (CMCT), all metal-oxygen (M–O) signals, including Ce–O (460 cm–1), Ti-O (350 cm–1), Co-O (200 cm–1), and Mn-O (621 cm–1), exhibit strong intensities and uniform spatial distribution, indicating homogeneous dispersion of active components. As the reaction progressed, a significant reduction in peak intensity was observed in CMCT-F, especially for Mn–O and Co–O. In CMCT-D, the peaks further weakened, with Mn–O and Co–O signals almost disappearing in some regions, while the Ce–O band remained relatively stable. After the removal of H2O and SO2 (CMCT-T), partial recovery of Raman signals was observed, but the spatial distribution remained non-uniform. These results indicate progressive degradation and redistribution of Mn and Co species during the reaction, with only partial regeneration after treatment. In contrast, Ti and Ce species maintained relatively stable structures throughout, highlighting the structural robustness of TiO2 and CeO2. Since the CMCT-I sample was not subjected to sulfation, its surface chemical state significantly differs from that of the sulfated samples. Therefore, XPS analysis was focused on CMCT, CMCT-F, CMCT-D, and CMCT-T to investigate the surface evolution of the catalyst during the sulfation and regeneration process. Figs. 3(a–c) , Fig. S6, and Table 1 show the main changes in surface electronic states, and full binding energy values, surface concentrations. Detailed elements analysis are summarized in Tables S2–S4. The binding energies of Mn 2p, Co 2p, Ce 3d, Ti 2p, and O 1s exhibited slight positive shifts (0.1–0.5 eV) after SO2 and H2O exposure, suggesting an overall decrease in surface electron density. In CMCT-D, the Ce 3d binding energy showed a distinct negative shift of 0.7 eV, accompanied by an increased Ce3+ fraction (from 20.76% to 26.55%), suggesting a partial reduction of Ce4+, likely due to the formation of Ce2(SO4)3 species stabilized by sulfate incorporation [53,54]. Similarly, the proportion of Mn2+ increased from 23.06% (CMCT) to 37.41% (CMCT-T), with corresponding declines in Mn3+ and Mn4+, consistent with the formation of manganese sulfate species [55]. In contrast, a significant decrease in the Ovac/Olat ratio was observed, from 60.38% in CMCT to 31.60% in CMCT-D, indicating the loss of surface oxygen vacancies. After the removal of SO2 and H2O, both the Ce3+ fraction and Ovac/Olat ratio partially recovered, indicating some reversibility in surface structure and defect density. In addition, S and N elements were detected on the sulfated samples (Table S4, Fig. S7), confirming the formation and retention of sulfur- and nitrogen-containing species on the catalyst surface [56,57]. The surface sulfur (S) content, as determined by XPS (Table 1), increased in CMCT-F (1.41%) and CMCT-T (1.15%), but slightly decreased in CMCT-D (0.91%), which does not directly correlate with catalytic activity. This discrepancy likely results from the surface sensitivity of XPS: with sulfation proceeds, some sulfate species migrate into the bulk or restructure, reducing surface detectability even as deactivation continues. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the average oxidation state of Mn declined sharply after SO2 and H2O exposure and then remained at a lower level, indicating progressive reduction of redox-active Mn species. As shown in Fig. 3(e), the surface atomic contents of N and S initially increased and then stabilized with prolonged SO2 and H2O exposure. Considering the theoretical N:S ratio ranges from 2:1 for (NH4)2SO4 to 1:1 for NH4HSO4, the measured S/N ratios were 0.66 for CMCT-F, 0.44 for CMCT-D, and 0.63 for CMCT-T. The temporary decrease in S/N in CMCT-D coincided with a lower detected surface sulfur content, which may be associated with the migration of sulfur species into deeper layers or transformation into less surface-accessible forms. After removal of SO2 and H2O, the S/N ratio in CMCT-T increased again, while the N content remained stable, consistent with the presence of residual sulfur species on the surface. Despite the overall activity loss (Fig. 3(f)), the continuous accumulation of sulfur on Ce and Ti reflected by increasing S/M (M=metal) ratios, suggests preferential sulfation of these sites, which may disrupt surface acidity or oxygen mobility. 3.3 Exploration of surface competitive adsorption capacity The dynamic adsorption behavior of the CMCT catalyst under different atmospheres was investigated using adsorption breakthrough testing. As shown in Fig. 4(a) , the adsorption breakthrough curve was measured at 50  °C to minimize thermal desorption and better reflect the intrinsic adsorption capacity of the catalyst surface under low-temperature conditions. The breakthrough time of NO + O2 was significantly shorter than that of NH3 and SO2 + O2, indicating that NO + O2 saturated the adsorption sites more quickly under these conditions. The adsorption rate of NH3 was slower, but its saturation adsorption capacity was higher than that of NO + O2. The adsorption rate of SO2 + O2 was the slowest, but its adsorption capacity increased significantly, demonstrating the strong adsorption ability of SO2. To semi-quantitatively compare the competitive adsorption behavior of different catalysts, a time-normalized adsorption response index was constructed based on TG data. Specifically, the initial mass (m 0) was combined with the time-resolved TG signal to calculate the absolute mass at each time point (m t), which was then normalized to the initial mass to obtain m c = m t/m 0. The cumulative change in m c over the 0–30 min interval () was calculated to reflect the overall adsorption response within a fixed time window. This approach allows for a direct comparison of adsorption dynamics between different samples and gas environments, independent of their equilibrium times or plateau positions. The resulting values (dimensionless, relative units) represent the integrated adsorption strength over the selected interval and the thermogravimetric curves shown in Fig. S8. To better compare the adsorption behavior across different gases and catalyst states, the TGA-derived uptake response integrals were extracted and used to calculate competitive selectivity coefficients. Their correlations are visualized in the matrix plots in Figs. 4(b), (c). These data were obtained under single- and mixed-gas conditions, and the detailed calculation procedures are provided in the Experimental Section. The pristine CMCT catalyst exhibited strong competitive adsorption of SO2 over NH3 and NO, with selectivity coefficients S SO2/NH3 = 14, and S SO2/NO = 11, indicating a clear adsorption preference for SO2 under initial conditions. After the SCR reaction (CMCT-I), the relative uptake response of all gases increased, particularly for NH3 (from 7.45 to 22.68, ~3.1 fold) and NO + SO2 (from 8.73 to 42.57, ~4.9 fold), reflecting enhanced surface activation and co-adsorption. Despite this, SO2 remained dominant, as shown by still-elevated selectivity coefficients. During stable sulfation (CMCT-F), the relative uptake response for all gases declined, with NH3 and NO experiencing the most significant drops (e.g., NH3 decreased from 22.68% to 1.74%, ~92% reduction). At this stage, S SO2/NH3 and S SO2/NO increased sharply to 45.3 and 30.1, respectively, confirming the strong inhibitory effect of SO2 on NH3 and NO adsorption under sulfation conditions. In the deep sulfation stage (CMCT-D), NH3 and NO uptakes partially recovered, while SO2 decreased. However, the simultaneous uptake of NH3 + NO dropped to 4.28  (~81.1% drop from CMCT-I), indicating impaired SCR adsorption synergy. After removal of H2O and SO2 (CMCT-T), NH3 and NO uptakes largely returned to initial levels, and selectivity coefficients declined below those of CMCT-I, suggesting partial reversibility of sulfation-induced inhibition. Overall, these results demonstrate that SO2 suppresses NH3 and NO adsorption via competitive interactions, particularly under stable sulfation. Nevertheless, the SCR adsorption behavior shows a degree of reversibility once the poisoning source is removed. The in-situ DRIFT spectra of SO2 + O2 co-adsorption over the CM (CoMn2O4), CT (CeTiO x ), and CMCT catalysts at 150 °C revealed distinct sulfate and sulfite deposition behaviors (Fig. 5(a) ). On the CM catalyst, peaks at 1617 cm–1 (HSO4 –), 1047 cm–1 (unidentate SO4 2–), 1235 cm–1 (chelating bidentate SO4 2–), and 1339 cm–1 (organic bidentate SO4 2–) were observed, with chelating bidentate SO4 2– formed via oxidative transformation of organic sulfites at 1269 cm–1 [58,60]. Bulk-phase sulfate (1166 cm–1) emerged from unidentate sulfate transformation, indicating sulfate accumulation [61,62]. In contrast, the CT support exhibited significantly reduced sulfate accumulation, demonstrating its anti-SO2 properties by minimizing SO2 adsorption and oxidation. For the CMCT catalyst, unidentate SO4 2– and organic sulfites (1040, 1135 and 1252 cm–1) were retained without bulk-phase sulfate formation [59]. The oxidation of SO2 plays a critical role in the deposition of ammonium bisulfate (ABS) on active sites, which can lead to the physical deactivation of SCR catalysts, particularly at low temperatures. To investigate this, the surface reactions of SO2 + O2 and NH3 were studied at 150 °C (Fig. 5(b)). Upon the introduction of NH3, the peaks associated with organic bidentate SO4 2– (1339 cm–1) disappeared, while new peaks corresponding to NH4⁺ (1433/1435, 1674, and 3000–3400 cm–1) emerged, confirming the physical deposition of ABS on the catalyst surface [63,64]. As shown in the normalized time-resolved FTIR profiles (Fig. 5(b), right), the intensity and growth rate of NH4⁺-related bands were highest for CM, moderate for CMCT, and lowest for CT. This trend indicates that the presence of Ce-Ti components in CMCT may mitigate ABS accumulation and delay physical deactivation. On the CM catalyst, all peaks exhibited a red shift, and the peak intensity at 1189 cm–1 remained stable, suggesting the persistence of bulk-phase sulfate. Additionally, a transformation from chelating bidentate SO4 2– (1235 cm–1) to HSO4 – (1243 cm–1) was observed [51]. In contrast, the CT and CMCT catalysts displayed a blue shift in their peaks, signifying the oxidation of organic sulfites (1270/1252 cm–1) to HSO4 – (1255/1245 cm–1) [2,65]. These results demonstrate that NH3 interacts with adsorbed SO4 2– species and converts them into less stable ammonium sulfate forms, thereby mitigating SO2 poisoning and enhancing the overall durability of the SCR catalysts. The degree of SO2 poisoning is closely related to the prevailing SCR reaction pathway, with the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism generally exhibiting greater resistance than the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) pathway [40]. This is because the E-R pathway involves gas-phase NH3 reacting directly with adsorbed NO x species, requiring fewer accessible surface adsorption sites, which are typically deactivated by SO2. To further explore this mechanistic aspect under our catalyst system, a series of adsorption and surface reaction characterizations were conducted. As shown in Fig. S9, transient adsorption experiments involving NH3 and NO + O2 revealed that CT and CMCT catalysts adsorbed more NH3 species than CM. Upon introducing NO + O2, all catalysts exhibited significant activity, indicating a strong E-R pathway. When the gas intake sequence was reversed, CM showed a higher concentration of surface nitrate species, which nearly disappeared after NH3 introduction, suggesting a dominant L-H pathway. In contrast, CT and CMCT retained detectable nitrate peaks, indicating a weaker L-H pathway and a stronger E-R mechanism. These results demonstrate that CMCT, influenced by the Ce-Ti carrier, primarily follows the E-R mechanism, which enhances its resistance to SO2 poisoning and improves SCR performance. To identify the adsorption sites of reactant molecules (NO, NH3, SO2) on the CMCT catalyst, the adsorption peaks were deconvoluted and compared with the characteristic peaks of the active component (CM) and support (CT), as shown in Fig. 6(a) . SO2 exhibited strong adsorption on CM (1166 and 1047 cm–1) with minimal interaction with CT, while NH3 showed concentrated adsorption on CM (1206 cm–1) and a broader distribution on CT. NO preferentially adsorbed on CM, with negligible adsorption on CT. The preferential adsorption of NO on Mn- and Co-based active components is attributed to their strong redox ability and vacant d orbitals, which facilitate π-type coordination. In contrast, NH3, as a Lewis base, can be adsorbed on both the redox-active metals and the acidic sites on the Ce-Ti oxide support, including both Lewis and Brönsted acid sites. These findings highlight the distinct adsorption behaviors of SO2, NH3, and NO on the CMCT catalyst, with SO2 and NO showing a strong preference for the active component CM, while NH3 exhibits both concentrated adsorption on CM and a more distributed adsorption on CT. This information provides valuable insights into the role of different adsorption sites in the SCR reaction. 3.4 Discussion Understanding the evolution and interaction of sulfur species on the catalyst surface is essential for revealing the deactivation mechanism of CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) under SO2 and H2O exposure during low-temperature NH3-SCR. In this study, combined characterizations confirmed that surface sulfation led to the formation of two major classes of sulfur-containing species: insoluble bulk metal sulfates, which caused irreversible deactivation by blocking redox-active sites and disturbing electron transfer; and ammonium bisulfate or (coordinated) metal sulfates, which reversibly deactivated the catalyst via surface coverage and pore blockage. These ammonium sulfate species were primarily formed through the reaction of NH3 with SO3 at temperatures below 200  °C, consistent with the thermodynamic favorability of SO2 oxidation at low temperatures. The generated SO3 may either deposit on the catalyst surface or be released into the flue gas, depending on the adsorption affinity of catalysts and local reaction environment [64–67]. Additionally, SO2 exhibited strong competitive adsorption behavior, which suppressed the uptake of NH3 and NO, thus disrupting the SCR process. Interestingly, the presence of NH3 also altered the surface sulfur speciation, promoting the conversion of adsorbed sulfur into more volatile ammonium sulfate forms, as evidenced by in situ DRIFTS analysis in Fig. 5(b). Furthermore, the CMCT was found to enhance SO2 resistance by stabilizing redox sites and facilitating the E-R mechanism. Because the E-R pathway depends less on surface-adsorbed NH3 than the L-H mechanism, it exhibits lower sensitivity to SO2-induced poisoning. These mechanistic insights provide a foundation for the subsequent discussion on the dynamic transformation of sulfate species and their direct impact on the SCR performance. 3.5 The transformation of sulfates The results in the TG analysis show the deposition of ammonium sulfates and metal sulfates in low temperatures (< 250 °C), the formation of metal sulfates under such mild conditions is likely facilitated by the prolonged exposure to SO2 and H2O, as well as the redox activity of transition metals, consistent with previous findings [43,68]. Compared to earlier studies, the use of time-resolved analysis in this work enables direct observation of sulfate species evolution during prolonged SCR reactions. Based on Fig. 1(d), the evolution of sulfate species can be divided into three stages: (1) Rapid accumulation of surface sulfates. Upon exposure to H2O and SO2, both ammonium sulfates (such as NH4HSO4 and (NH4)2SO4) and metal (coordinated) sulfates rapidly accumulate on the catalyst surface. The formation of ammonium sulfates is favored by the presence of Brönsted acid sites and available NH3 under SCR conditions, which can be described by the following reactions, which occur in the presence of SO3 (produced from SO2 oxidation) and H2O: (7) NH3 (gas) + SO3 (ads) + H2O (ads) → NH4HSO4 (ads) (8) 2NH3 (gas) + SO3 (ads) + H2O (ads) → (NH4)2SO4 (ads) This process is evidenced by the appearance of low-temperature TG weight loss and enhanced Brönsted acid peaks after introduced H2O and SO2 (Fig. 7(a) ). Furthermore, subsequent exposure to NO + O2 promotes the decomposition of these surface ammonium sulfate species, as demonstrated by the observed decrease in ammonium sulfate bands (see below for mechanistic details and reaction equation Eq. (12)). XPS analysis (Fig. 3 and Table 1) reveals an increased proportion of low-valence metal species (e.g., Mn2+, Co2+, Ce3+), indicative of metal sulfate formation. The observed surface S/N ratio exceeding the theoretical 2:1 value for pure ammonium sulfates (Fig. 3(e)), which further confirms the coexistence of metal sulfates. Raman mapping (Fig. 2) showed more significant attenuation in Mn–O and Co–O bands, this does not contradict the proposed initial sulfation of Ce and Ti sites (Fig. 3(f)). Ce4+ and Ti4+, with their strong affinity for SO4 2– and H2O, tend to form surface-coordinated sulfates through mono-/bidentate or bridging modes without disrupting the oxide lattice, thereby retaining Raman activity. In contrast, Mn and Co sites are more susceptible to irreversible transformations, such as valence shifts (e.g., Mn3+ → Mn2+) and formation of metal sulfates (e.g., MnSO4, CoSO4), which lead to signal weakening or loss. (2) Transformation from surface to bulk sulfates. With prolonged sulfation, some surface sulfates transitioned into bulk sulfates. Surface sulfate species (e.g., SO4 2–, HSO4 –) preferentially bond with metal oxides [62]. In CMCT system, this irreversible transformation is supported by multiple lines of evidence: the decrease in surface S content observed by XPS (Table 1), accompanied by a concurrent increase in thermally stable, water-insoluble sulfated species in TG analysis (Figs. 1(b), (c)), which points to the formation and accumulation of bulk-phase metal sulfates. Furthermore, spatially resolved SEM-EDS and Raman mapping results further support this mechanism. While EDS directly reveals the progressive accumulation of sulfur species at and beneath the catalyst surface during sulfation, Raman mapping shows persistent loss and spatial inhomogeneity of Mn-O and Co-O phases even after SO2 removal. This strong spatial correlation between sulfates distribution and active phase degradation provides evidence that subsurface or bulk sulfate accumulation and irreversible restructuring of active sites, thus leading to continued catalyst deactivation. While surface sulfates are typically weakly bound and partially reversible, the transformation into lattice-bound metal sulfates leads to structural changes and deactivation. XRD (Fig. S3), FT-IR (Fig. S5) and Raman (Fig. 3) analyses further revealed the evolution of sulfate-related crystalline features. Similar surface-to-bulk sulfation has been reported for other systems, such as the conversion of ammonium bisulfate into bidentate SO4 2– and further into crystalline (NH4)2TiO(SO4)2 on V2O₅/TiO2 catalysts [64]. (3) Decomposition and reduction of metal sulfates: After the removal of H2O and SO2, the content of metal sulfates (both surface and bulk) decreased may due to decomposition and reduction. Studies have shown that surface-bound amorphous sulfate species, such as non-crystalline SO4 2– adsorbed on metal oxides or unstructured precursor forms of metal sulfates, begin to decompose at around 250  °C [2]. Another study showed the thermal decomposition of Ce(SO4)2 and its transformation to CeOSO4 occur around 200 °C [69]. Additionally, at 150 °C, the deposition and decomposition rates of sulfates on Mn/Ce-400-Air are nearly balanced, attributed to the Ce3+/Ce4+ redox cycle [70]. These research results are similar to our experimental observations, such as the relatively stable S/Ce ratio (Fig. 3(f)) and the relatively stable Raman characteristic peaks of CeO2 (Fig. 2). The following Ce equilibrium reactions can be proposed: (9) 2CeO2 (s) + 3SO2 (gas) + O2 (gas) → Ce2(SO4)3 (ads) (10) Ce2(SO4)3 (ads) + 4NH3 (gas) + 3H2O (gas) → Ce2O3 (s) + (NH4)2SO4 (ads) + 2NH4HSO4 (ads) (11) 2Ce2O3 (s) + O2 (gas) → 4CeO2 (s) After removal of H2O and SO2, Reaction (1) is interrupted due to the absence of reactants, while Reactions (2), (3) may proceed, as H2O is continuously generated from the SCR reaction itself, providing a source for further transformation of residual Ce-sulfates into ammonium sulfates. Meanwhile, exposed oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface can adsorb SO4 2‒ species, promoting the outward migration of bulk sulfates. Additionally, while peak deconvolution suggests a higher tendency for SO2 adsorption on active components (Fig. 6(a)), the contribution of Ce-Ti support also plays a critical role, as shown by the initially higher S/Ce and S/Ti ratios (Fig. 3(f)) and the increased contribution of inhibiting SO2 adsorption (Fig. 5(a)). Notably, the Ti component in the CeTiO x support remains chemically stable, as indicated by the negligible changes in Ti 2p 3/2 binding energy (Table S2) and serves to preserve the catalyst acid-base properties during sulfation and regeneration. This structural robustness, together with the acid-site modulation by TiO2, may suppress excessive SO2 oxidation and thus mitigate sulfate accumulation, supporting the observed sulfur resistance. The role of Ti in anchoring and subsequently releasing surface sulfates under SCR conditions highlights the cooperative effect between Ce and Ti sites in maintaining catalyst activity. The schematic of this process is illustrated in Fig. 6(b), presenting a stage-wise mechanism for sulfate evolution and its contribution to catalyst deactivation and recovery. 3.6 Influence of the sulfation process on SCR performance Long-term SCR stability under SO2 and H2O conditions has been demonstrated by several high-temperature catalysts. For example, Ce-MoTiOx maintained over 80% NO x conversion at 300  °C for 144  h under 250  × 10–6 SO2, while MnO x /CeO2 nanorods showed nearly 100% conversion at 250  °C for 1000  h under 200  × 10–6 SO2 [2,71]. Such robustness is largely attributed to the high temperature, which promotes the decomposition and volatilization of surface sulfates, thereby restoring oxygen vacancies and maintaining active site availability for NH3 adsorption and reaction. In contrast, at low temperatures (< 200  °C), sulfates are thermodynamically more stable and tend to accumulate on the catalyst surface. NH3 can further react with these sulfates to form ammonium bisulfate or sulfate species, which not only block surface active sites but also consume oxygen vacancies, thereby suppressing SCR efficiency [72]. The presence of H2O exacerbates this process by facilitating the formation and deposition of ammonium salts, resulting in faster deactivation. To better contextualize these challenges, we summarized the low-temperature (< 200 °C) performance of transition metal oxide catalysts with simultaneous resistance to H2O and SO2, as shown in Table S5. The catalysts are listed in ascending order of stability duration under poisoning conditions, thereby facilitating direct comparison of deactivation tolerance across different systems. Most catalysts exhibited poor durability, with stable operation typically limited to less than 5 h and NO x conversion below 80%. Only a few systems achieved over 10  h of stable performance. For example, among the best-performing catalysts in Table S5, the Co-Ce-Ti catalyst maintained >90% NO x conversion for 35 h [73], the Sm-Mn catalyst achieved 91% conversion for 14 h [74], and the Co-MnO x spinel rod sustained 86% conversion for 10 h under similar conditions [17]. CMCT outperforms these top systems by 7–36 h at comparable or higher conversion levels, highlighting its superior resistance to SO2 and H2O poisoning. Our results in Fig. 1(a) showed a long-time test for SCR stability under H2O and SO2 condition. Although the CMCT catalyst eventually experienced deactivation under prolonged SO2 and H2O exposure, it sustained high activity (> 80% NO x conversion) for over 42  h, significantly outperforming most reported systems. Furthermore, after cessation of SO2 and H2O flow, the SCR activity rapidly recovered, which is consistent with the trends observed for most catalysts in Table S5, indicating that part of the deactivation was reversible. These findings not only validate the performance advantage of CMCT under realistic conditions but also provide mechanistic insights into the roles of sulfate species in catalyst deactivation and regeneration, addressing a critical knowledge gap in the field. Our study reveals distinct activity influence mechanism across different reaction stages, highlighting the critical role of competitive adsorption alongside sulfate deposition in shaping catalyst performance. Based on the time-resolved analysis, we analyzed the mechanism for the four stages as follows: (1) Stable SCR reaction phase During this phase, catalytic activity remained at 100% (Fig. 1(a)), with the SCR reaction following both L-H and E-R mechanisms (Fig. S9). The support enhanced NH3 adsorption (Fig. 6(a)), and its activation was promoted by the SCR reaction. The significant increase in simultaneous NO and SO2 adsorption in CMCT-I further corroborates this observation (Fig. 4(b)). (2) Fluctuation phase under H2O and SO2 exposure After introducing H2O and SO2, the NO x conversion rate slightly decreased, exhibiting a fluctuation between 84%–87% until 42 h. This fluctuation is primarily caused by the dynamic competition among H2O, SO2 (especially SO2), and reactant molecules (NO x and NH3) for adsorption on the catalyst surface (Figs. 4 and 5). As competitive adsorption and surface coverage evolve, the accessibility and distribution of active sites shift, leading to the observed activity variation. Sustained activity was primarily due to H2O suppressing SO2 adsorption, pre-sulfation of the support, and partial sulfate decomposition. As shown in Fig. 7(a), H2O weakened the adsorption of reactant molecules (1199, 1232 cm–1) but promoted the formation of Brönsted acid sites (NH4⁺, 3600–3000 cm–1) [40,75]. In contrast, SO2 adsorption not only occupied reactant adsorption sites but also generated new sulfate species (1246, 1128, and 1017 cm–1). When H2O and SO2 were co-introduced, the adsorption intensity of reactant peaks was similar to or lower than with H2O alone, indicating that H2O can effectively suppress SO2 adsorption. This is consistent with the continued detection of SO2 in Fig. 1(a). However, strong Brönsted acid peaks also indicated accelerated formation of ammonium sulfate. These results demonstrate the dual role of H2O: it mitigates irreversible sulfation by limiting SO2 adsorption and metal sulfate formation, thereby helping to sustain catalyst activity. At the same time, H2O enhances Brönsted acidity and facilitates the formation of reversible ammonium sulfate, which can temporarily inhibit activity by blocking active sites. Overall, H2O helps mitigate irreversible deactivation in the short term, but with prolonged exposure, promotes reversible sulfate accumulation and associated transient activity loss. Although SO2 competitive adsorption and sulfate deposition significantly inhibited NO and NH3 adsorption, simultaneous NH3 + NO adsorption remained largely available in CMCT-F (Fig. 4(b)), indicating that the SCR reaction could still proceed with sufficient adsorption and redox sites. To demonstrate adsorption site reactivity, we separately introduced NH3 and NO + O2 to the SCR catalyst pretreated with H2O and SO2 for 1 hour, as shown in Fig. 7(b) NH3 enhanced Brönsted acid (3000–3600 cm–1) and Lewis acid (1193 cm–1) peaks, while NO + O2 gradually reduced ammonium sulfate bands (3000–3600 and 1203 cm–1), indicating NO + O2 promoted ammonium sulfate decomposition on the catalyst [64,76]. The reaction is as follows: (12) (NH4)2SO4 (ads) + 2NH4HSO4 (ads) + 2NO (gas) + 1/2O2 (gas) → 3N2 (gas) + 9H2O (gas) + 3SO2 (gas) While some studies suggest that AS/ABS decomposition requires high temperatures (>300 °C) [44,76], others support its occurrence at low temperatures, such as the complete consumption of ammonium bisulfate on CeWO x at 200 °C [68], which aligns with our findings. Therefore, the reversible nature of ammonium sulfate deposition and decomposition under SCR conditions directly contributes to the observed recovery of catalytic activity after SO2 removal, by re-exposing previously blocked active sites. Regarding redox capacity, although SO2 or sulfates caused a reduction in Mn oxidation state and oxygen vacancies, the increase in Ce3+ and the formation of cerium sulfates protected active components and provided additional oxygen vacancies (Fig. 3(d) and Fig. 8(a) ). (3) Descend phase under H2O and SO2 exposure After 42 h, SO2 was no longer detectable at the outlet, suggesting that nearly all incoming SO2 was retained and transformed into surface sulfate species, with little or none released to the gas phase, reflecting a saturation regime in the sulfation kinetics. As sulfation intensified, the NO x conversion rate dropped to 67% by 65 h. The primary cause of deactivation during this phase was the intensification of sulfation, leading to the formation of bulk-phase sulfates. Although competitive adsorption persisted, its intensity significantly decreased (Fig. 4(c)). As the reaction progressed, the support reached adsorption saturation and began to decompose, as evidenced by the reduction in Ce3+ content (Fig. 8(a)). Meanwhile, the decomposition or transformation of surface ammonium sulfates (AS/ABS) partially exposed previously blocked adsorption sites, enhancing individual NO and NH3 uptake (Fig. 4(b)). These sites likely included Lewis acid sites and oxygen vacancies that were temporarily covered by surface-deposited sulfates. However, the simultaneous adsorption of NO and NH3 declined sharply, indicating that sulfate accumulation hindered co-adsorption on adjacent sites required for the SCR reaction. This is consistent with the observed decrease in oxygen vacancy content (Fig. 8(a)), which limited redox cycling capacity. In addition to chemical deactivation, physical deposition also played a role. The appearance of visible white deposits on the reactor walls (Fig. S4) suggests that volatile ammonium salts (e.g., (NH4)2SO4, NH4HSO4) migrated and condensed downstream under humid conditions, contributing to physical pore blockage and loss of active material from the reaction zone [77]. These combined factors, chemical poisoning, loss of redox function, and physical deposition collectively led to the irreversible decline in SCR performance during this stage. (4) Recovery phase after the removal of H2O and SO2 Following the discontinuation of H2O and SO2, the NO x conversion rate recovers to over 90%, indicating that the effects of some sulfates are reversible. This recovery is primarily attributed to the decomposition of metal sulfates (such as Ce-based species) and the re-exposure of active sites, including oxygen vacancies and acid sites, that were previously blocked by sulfate species. Upon removal of external H2O and SO2, the residual Ce-sulfates can continue to decompose, while some bulk sulfates migrate toward the surface and further react with NH3 to form ammonium sulfates. These ammonium sulfate species (AS/ABS) can be further decomposed or consumed through reactions with NO and O2 through reaction (Eq. (12)), generating gaseous products such as N2, H2O, and possibly SO2, though no direct gas-phase evidence was collected in this study to confirm their desorption pathways. Nevertheless, due to the large amount of previously adsorbed sulfur species, the total AS/ABS content remains high at this stage (Fig. 1(d)), indicating that complete desulfation was not achieved. In parallel, the decomposition of ammonium sulfates helped restore Brönsted acid sites, thereby enhancing NH3 adsorption. As shown in Fig. 4(b), the regenerated catalyst (CMCT-T) exhibited even stronger NH3 and NO uptake than the fresh sample (CMCT), supporting the notion that certain active sites became more accessible after desorption or migration of surface sulfates. Furthermore, the TOF values of the catalyst at different sulfation stages were evaluated in the temperature range of 50–120  °C (Fig. S10). Compared with the fresh catalyst, the TOF values of post-sulfation samples decreased, indicating that sulfation impairs low-temperature intrinsic activity. The order of TOF performance was: CMCT-F > CMCT-T > CMCT-D, suggesting partial but incomplete recovery of catalytic function. A schematic of the reaction mechanism at each stage helps to better understand the process (Fig. 8(b)). Overall, ammonium sulfates may not be the primary cause of deactivation since it can participate in the SCR reaction as a reaction site and continue to adsorb reactants after being consumed. Instead, the main reasons for activity decline are the presence of bulk metal sulfates and competitive adsorption. However, as long as sufficient active sites remain, removing water and sulfur can gradually alleviate the impacts of poisoning and deactivation. However, due to the substantial amount of previously accumulated sulfated species, complete desulfation may not be achieved within the studied timescale, as evidenced by the persistently elevated AS/ABS content in Fig. 1(d). 3.7 Limitations and future perspectives This study provides critical insights into the sulfation mechanism affecting the performance of the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) catalyst under low-temperature SCR conditions, yet several limitations must be acknowledged. The focus on a specific catalyst composition and controlled laboratory conditions may not fully replicate the complex and dynamic environments encountered in industrial applications, limiting the generalizability of the findings to other catalyst or higher temperature regimes. While advanced characterization techniques, such as XPS, FT-IR, and in-situ DRIFTS, effectively elucidated the role of sulfate species in catalyst deactivation, they may not capture all transient molecular-level phenomena during the reaction. Future research should employ more dynamic in-situ analytical methods, such as operando spectroscopy, to observe real-time interactions and explore the long-term stability and regeneration capacity of SCR catalysts under fluctuating environmental conditions. 4 Conclusions This research elucidated the sulfation mechanism of the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x catalyst under SO2 and H2O exposure during NH3-SCR at 150 °C. The evolution of sulfate species was characterized by three clearly defined stages: initial rapid surface sulfate accumulation, progressive transformation of these species into bulk metal sulfates, and partial decomposition following the removal of sulfur and water gases. The results demonstrate that bulk metal sulfates induce irreversible deactivation by altering lattice structures and reducing oxygen vacancies. In contrast, ammonium sulfates and certain surface-coordinated metal sulfates primarily induce reversible performance loss through surface blockage and subsequent decomposition under typical SCR conditions, enabling partial regeneration of activity. Furthermore, the competitive adsorption between H2O and SO2 significantly impacts catalyst performance; the presence of H2O inhibits SO2 adsorption and facilitates the formation of Brönsted acid sites, thus initially maintaining catalyst activity. However, continuous sulfate deposition and persistent competitive adsorption by SO2 lead to progressive and sustained catalyst performance decline. These mechanistic insights clarify the dual roles of sulfur species in catalyst deactivation and recovery, establishing a detailed framework for managing sulfur-related issues in SCR system. Ultimately, this work outlines effective strategies to balance sulfation resistance with regeneration capability, guiding the design of next-generation SCR catalysts for stable operation in environments with fluctuating levels of sulfur and moisture. coredata.dc:description: The problem of water and sulfur poisoning in flue gas atmosphere remains a significant obstacle for low-temperature deNO x catalysts. This study investigated the sulfation mechanism of the CoMn2O4/CeTiO x (CMCT) catalyst during the selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3 under conditions containing H2O and SO2 at 150 °C. Employing a comprehensive suite of time-resolved analysis and characterization techniques, the evolution of sulfate species was systematically categorized into three stages: initial rapid surface sulfate accumulation, the transformation of surface sulfates to bulk metal sulfates, and partial sulfates decomposition after the removal of H2O and SO2. These findings indicate that bulk metal sulfates irreversibly deactivate the catalyst by distorting active component lattices and consuming oxygen vacancies, whereas surface sulfates (including ammonium sulfates and surface-coordinated metal sulfates) cause reversible performance loss through decomposition. Furthermore, the competitive adsorption of H2O and SO2 significantly influences the catalytic efficiency, with H2O suppressing SO2 adsorption while simultaneously enhancing the formation of Brönsted acid sites. This research underscores the critical role of sulfate dynamics on catalyst performance, revealing the enhanced SO2 resistance of the Eley-Rideal mechanism facilitated by the Ce-Ti support relative to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood pathway. Collectively, the study unravels the complex interplay of sulfate dynamics influencing catalyst performance and provides potential approaches to mitigate deactivation in demanding atmospheric conditions.
